page.title: 01Blandford Forum - Gazetteer
page.content: Almost entirely destroyed by fire in 1731 Blandford Forum is a lovely Georgian town with attractive narrow streets and an interesting roof pattern typical of its time. Its re- building over 30 years led to a uniform character of architecture and to inclusion in the Council of British Archaeology's list of 51 towns of national importance. The spacious Market Place,Town Hall,Parish Church and Coupar House are perfect examples of Georgian architecture. For contrast nearby are two buildings which escaped the fire,'The Old House' in the Close and the Ryves Almshouses founded in 1682.The manor is referred to in the 1086 Domesday Survey as Chipping Blaneford. It lies 18 miles North West of Bournemouth on the river Stour where it cuts through the rolling chalk Dorset Downs.
